Purattasi is the sixth month in the Tamil calendar and is dedicated to Lord Perumal (Lord Venkateswara), as it is believed that Lord Venkateswara appeared on the earth during this month. Devotees gather in large numbers at Lord Vishnu temples and special prayers are offered and flags with Garuda emblem are hoisted.

Purattasi Vrat is observed by devotees of Lord Venkateswara. Some people observe partial fasting on all days in Puratassi whilst others limit it to Saturdays. A few observe strict fast called Nirjala Vratam on Saturdays which involves not even drinking a drop of water.

Mahalaya Paksham that started on the 9th of September, on the full moon day of Aavani, completes with Mahalaya Ammavasai on the 24th of September. Why is Mahalaya Paksham so important? Why we do not perform any Subha Karyam during this time? What is the basic dhatham (offering) that we should do? All these are briefed in the article.

Navarathri

Of course the most important festival celebrated this month is Navaratri, which starts on 25th September. Navratri is a nine day festival dedicated to worship of the goddess in the three forms of Durga, Lakshmi and Saraswathi and the tenth day is celebrated as Vijayadashami. Whether we worship Devi in the form of Durga, Lakshmi or Saraswathi, we really worship the ultimate Sakti – ‘Parasakti’. In Lalitha Sahasranamam Devi is at once described the creator (Shrishtikarthee and brahmarupa), the preserver (gopthri, govindarupini) and destroyer (samharini, rudrarupini). In both Lakshmi and Saraswathi astothrams, we call Her ‘brahma-vishnu-sivathmikaaya’, signifying that Durga, Saraswathi and Lakshmi are one and the same. Please click here for a very interesting and useful article on Navarathri.

Saundarya Lahari, the thirty-two names of Durga and all the other Navaratri chants and practices are designed to awaken the human psyche. Just as there is a mental level, an emotional level, a pranic level and a physical level, so there is a vibratory level to our life as well. This vibratory level is the most subtle of the bodies and the only thing it responds to is frequency. Mantras create such frequencies in the body, in the personality, which stimulate and awaken the subtle personality.

This opening up of the subtle personality is also opening up of the heart. Logic governs life up to a point. After logic, buddhi, comes faith, bhavana, and after faith comes fusion, tadatmya. When this fusion takes place in us at a subtle psychic level, a spiritual level, we become more sensitive to the universe, life, spirit, creation. We learn to live life in a more responsible way, appreciating and applying the wisdom that has been gained through the ages. Mantras are definitely the keys to finding this inner awakening.

‘Siva Sukhap Peruvellam’ is a Tamil translation of ‘Shivanandalahari’ by Bhagavan Adi Sankara. This book comprises of 100 Sanskrit verses praising ‘Parabrahmam’ (the union of Shiva and Shakti). The main emphasis of Shivanandalahari is portraying the perspectives of a sincere aspirant, seeking the benign grace of God. One of our members is publishing a book on Soundaryalahari and on Lord Dakshinamurthy on the 5th of October. Details on the website.

We wish you a happy Navarathri and pray the almighty to shower blessings to all of us.
